hints_html: If we want to find a solution for all f(r), we’re going to need to find an orthogonality relation. How can we use Sturm-Liouville theory to find it?
hints_latex:
If we want to find a solution for all f(r), we're going to need to find
an orthogonality relation. How can we use Sturm-Liouville theory to find
it?
hints_raw: If we want to find a solution for all f(r), we're going to need to find an orthogonality relation.  How can we use Sturm-Liouville theory to find it?
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
In part (a) we found a solution for a specific f(r) that happened to be one of the original eigenfunctions and so we were able to compare just by analyzing the coefficient of one term. However now we have a general f(r) and if we continue from part (a) we have,

\[\begin{aligned} u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = f(r).\end{aligned}\]

We wish to impose an orthogonality argument so that we can isolate each individual coefficient, \(B_n\). Recall that if we have a problem in Sturm-Liouville form,

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\textrm{d}}{\textrm{d}r}\left(p(r)\frac{\textrm{d}\psi}{\textrm{d}r}\right)-q(r)\psi+\sigma(r)\mu\psi=0\end{aligned}\]

then the eigenfunctions \(\psi\) have the orthogonality relationship

\[\begin{aligned} \int_a^b\psi_n\psi_m\sigma(r)\textrm{d}r=0,\quad{}n\neq{m}.\end{aligned}\]

Our eigenfunction problem for r was

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}r^2 R'' + r R' + \left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}} \right)^2 R = 0\end{aligned}\]

which we can write in Sturm-Liouville form to get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\textrm{d}}{\textrm{d}r}\left(r\frac{\textrm{d}R}{\textrm{d}r}\right)+\frac{1}{{\color{blue} r}} \left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}} \right)^2 R=0\end{aligned}\]

so our orthogonality relation is

\[\begin{aligned} &\int_a^b\frac{R_nR_m}{{\color{blue} r}}\textrm{d}r\\&=\int_1^2\sin\left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\sin\left(\frac{m\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\end{aligned}\]

If we compute the integrals we can use a substitution of

\[\begin{aligned} x&=\frac{\ln{r}}{\ln{2}}\\ \textrm{d}x&=\frac{1}{\ln{2}}\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\end{aligned}\]

to get

\[\begin{aligned} \ln{2}\int_0^1\sin\left(n\pi{x}\right)\sin\left(m\pi{x}\right)\textrm{d}x.\end{aligned}\]

We immediately recognize this new integral as the standard sine orthogonality relation and so we get

\[\begin{aligned} &\int_1^2\sin\left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\sin\left(\frac{m\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\\ &=\ln{2}\int_0^1\sin\left(n\pi{x}\right)\sin\left(m\pi{x}\right)\textrm{d}x= \begin{cases} 0&, n\neq{m}\\ \frac{\ln{2}}{2}&, n=m \end{cases}.\end{aligned}\]

Returning to

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = f(r)\end{aligned}\]

we can use our orthogonality relation to get

\[\begin{aligned} &B_n\sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\frac{\ln{2}}{2}=\int_1^2f(r)\sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\\ &B_n=\frac{2}{\ln{2}}\frac{1}{\sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right)}\int_1^2f(r)\sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we now have the constants \(B_m\) for any \(f(r)\) and therefore we have the solution to the partial differential equation,

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,\theta)= \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \theta\right).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
In [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH257/December_2011/Question_5_(a)|part (a)]] we found a solution for a specific f(r) that happened to be one of the original eigenfunctions and so we were able to compare just by analyzing the coefficient of one term.  However now we have a general f(r) and if we continue from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH257/December_2011/Question_5_(a)|part (a)]] we have,

:<math>
u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = f(r)
</math>.

We wish to impose an orthogonality argument so that we can isolate each individual coefficient, <math>B_n</math>.  Recall that if we have a problem in Sturm-Liouville form,

:<math>
\frac{\textrm{d}}{\textrm{d}r}\left(p(r)\frac{\textrm{d}\psi}{\textrm{d}r}\right)-q(r)\psi+\sigma(r)\mu\psi=0
</math>

then the eigenfunctions <math>\psi</math> have the orthogonality relationship

:<math>
\int_a^b\psi_n\psi_m\sigma(r)\textrm{d}r=0,\quad{}n\neq{m}.
</math>

Our eigenfunction problem for r was

:<math>
\displaystyle{}r^2 R'' + r R' + \left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}} \right)^2 R = 0
</math>

which we can write in Sturm-Liouville form to get

:<math>
\frac{\textrm{d}}{\textrm{d}r}\left(r\frac{\textrm{d}R}{\textrm{d}r}\right)+\frac{1}{{\color{blue} r}} \left( \frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}} \right)^2 R=0
</math>

so our orthogonality relation is

:<math>
\begin{align}
&\int_a^b\frac{R_nR_m}{{\color{blue} r}}\textrm{d}r\\
&=\int_1^2\sin\left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\sin\left(\frac{m\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r
\end{align}.
</math>

If we compute the integrals we can use a substitution of

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=\frac{\ln{r}}{\ln{2}}\\
\textrm{d}x&=\frac{1}{\ln{2}}\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r
\end{align}
</math>

to get
:<math>
\ln{2}\int_0^1\sin\left(n\pi{x}\right)\sin\left(m\pi{x}\right)\textrm{d}x.
</math>

We immediately recognize this new integral as the standard sine orthogonality relation and so we get

:<math>
\begin{align}
&\int_1^2\sin\left(\frac{n\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\sin\left(\frac{m\pi}{\ln{2}}\ln{r}\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\\
&=\ln{2}\int_0^1\sin\left(n\pi{x}\right)\sin\left(m\pi{x}\right)\textrm{d}x=
\begin{cases}
0&, n\neq{m}\\
\frac{\ln{2}}{2}&, n=m
\end{cases}.
\end{align}
</math>

Returning to
:<math>
\sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = f(r)
</math>

we can use our orthogonality relation to get

:<math>
\begin{align}
&B_n\sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right)\frac{\ln{2}}{2}=\int_1^2f(r)\sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r\\
&B_n=\frac{2}{\ln{2}}\frac{1}{\sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right)}\int_1^2f(r)\sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right)\frac{1}{r}\textrm{d}r.
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore we now have the constants <math>B_m</math> for any <math>f(r)</math> and therefore we have the solution to the partial differential equation,

:<math>
u(r,\theta)=  \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \theta\right).
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the following problem involving Laplace’s equation in an annular region:

\[\begin{aligned} u_{rr} + \frac1{r} u_r + \frac1{r^2}u_{\theta \theta} = 0, \quad 1 < r < 2, \quad 0 < \theta < \pi/2.\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} u(1,\theta) = 0, \quad u(2,\theta) = 0, \quad u(r,0) = 0, \quad u(r,\pi/2) = f(r).\end{aligned}\]

Find the solution for a general function \(f(r)\).
statement_raw:
Consider the following problem involving Laplace's equation in an annular region:

:<math>
u_{rr} + \frac1{r} u_r + \frac1{r^2}u_{\theta \theta} = 0,  \quad 1 < r < 2, \quad 0 < \theta < \pi/2.
</math>

:<math>
u(1,\theta) = 0, \quad u(2,\theta) = 0, \quad u(r,0) = 0, \quad u(r,\pi/2) = f(r).
</math>

Find the solution for a general function <math>f(r)</math>.
